380188: Into the Roil.author: Ataraxiom
380188: Into the Roil.text_parsed:
A beloved card sees it's first "reprint", more or less.

Jace's deck should be able to make great use of this, especially since it's one of the few cards that he can use directly against Vraska the Unseen. The option for card draw is great, and reusing your creatures' enters-the-battlefield effects should be really handy.

I do think a lot of people will be disappointed at the lack of new art, though.

Hilarious flavourtext. It's nice to see Vraska hanging out with some Ravnican locals, especially this dude who looks like he's casually strumming on the strangest electric guitar ever made.

Having three power should be great for slowing down Jace's beatdown assault, and the effect is liable to really mess with hand tempo as well. Just be careful with what goes up top, Future Sight and Jace's Mindseeker are both cards that could turn this kind of an effect into an advantage for the other player.

380190: Jace, Architect of Thought.author: Ataraxiom
380190: Jace, Architect of Thought.text_parsed:
I think that of the two decks, Vraska is going to have more sheer power, especially considering that her -3 can kill Jace directly. Jace players are going to have to get pretty clever, but that's why they're blue mages to begin with, right?

On a side note, Jace's +1 should go a long way to keeping Vraska's Assassin tokens away from your neck, so that's a plus.

Edit: I just realized that if you manage to get Jace's -8 to go off, you can actually cast Vraska the Unseen from her own deck. Kind of cool how each Planeswalker's ultimate ability is like an alternate ending to the duel.

Default Ending: One Planeswalker beats the other, while the loser escapes with their life.
Alternate Ending 1: Jace uses his mind magic to convert Vraska to his cause, securing peace in Ravnica.
Alternate Ending 2: Vraska's assassins kill Jace, upsetting the balance in Ravnica forever.

I'm not sure if I'm the only one who does this, but I always like to imagine the two planeswalkers actually dueling in the locations that're on my land cards. Kind of adds to the fantasy aspect of the game, you know?

With that in mind, I'm always happy to see such gorgeous artwork on lands, and these are no exception, even if they're just reprints.

I think I like variation 2 the best. It shows the prettier side of Ravnica, and always reminded me of the artwork on Ancestral Vision for some reason.

People are often distracted by the ability on a card when they see it as a downside rather than as an extra option. Creature typing aside, this lady is strictly better than a slew of 2/1 Black vanillas, and that's going to make her a very solid curve filler in Vraska's deck.

Flavourwise, I've got to agree with Voidweaver on this one, I simply adore the kind of crew that Vraska brings with her. They give her so much personality, even if we haven't learned much about her yet.

380196: Spawnwrithe.author: Ataraxiom
380196: Spawnwrithe.text_parsed:
I suppose this thing is kind of a like a snake or a hydra. It's downright creepy and it fits Vraska perfectly, right down to the dim lighting in the art.

I can see a lovely combo forming between Spawnwrithe and Drooling Groodion. Sacrifice a creature to the Groodion's effect, boost Spawnwrithe into a 4/4 Trampler, disable the blocker with the -2/-2, and get yourself a token. Next turn you can do it all over again by sacrificing the Spawnwrithe token in order to buff the original!

Shadow Alley Denizen and Rogue's Passage will also help out in a big way here. Needless to say, the Jace player ought to get rid of this thing in a hurry, or he'll be up to his neck in wrigglers.

380197: Riftwing Cloudskate.author: N03y3D33R
380197: Riftwing Cloudskate.text_parsed: A Man-o-War with evasion that can resist being discarded by being trapped in time actually seems rather logical to use against black. Kudos, design team.
380197: Riftwing Cloudskate.text_posted: A Man-o-War with evasion that can resist being discarded by being trapped in time actually seems rather logical to use against black. Kudos, design team.

380197: Riftwing Cloudskate.author: Ataraxiom
380197: Riftwing Cloudskate.text_parsed:
Not only is this guy in the ever-important Illusion tribe, but his suspension serves a very unique purpose against Vraska's deck.

Since the Vraska player is going to be able to watch the Cloudskate tick down, they're likely going to be very hesitant to play Vraska the Unseen, lest she should get bounced away before she can become useful. This is great news for the Jace player since there are so few ways to effectively deal with Vraska beyond beating her down with creature damage (not a fantastic idea with Vraska's +1 floating around).

In the case that there isn't anything on the other side of the field worth bouncing, you can always bounce an Archaeomancer, Body Double, Jace's Mindseeker, or even the Cloudskate itself for extra value.

The real beauty of Jace's deck is that each card can be used in so many different ways that no two matches will ever be the same. Ought to be a great time come March.

380199: Memory Lapse.author: Ataraxiom
380199: Memory Lapse.text_parsed:
Beyond it's usual anti-draw tempo effect, this should combo really well with the milling in Jace's deck if you feel the need to get rid of something particularly threatening, like an Acidic Slime, or maybe even Vraska herself.

Remember that if you counter an instant or sorcery spell with this, it'll be in the perfect position for you to steal it with Jace's Mindseeker. Milling for 5 and then stealing a Grisly Spectacle, killing a creature, and milling for more is the sort of thing that's going to make for some really memorable games.

I've got to agree with the others here though, this artwork doesn't feel quite right for Jace. The old puzzle-piece artwork would have gone really well with Jace's flavourtext there.

380199: Memory Lapse.author: Mode
380199: Memory Lapse.text_parsed:
"They had to stick with this art?" —Syrtees

     Wow, I'm surprised this comment is currently actually rated five stars. When I went to the comment section for this
     card, I actually expected the top comment to be from one of the Rebecca Guay fanboys, praising the original Mirage
     artwork.

"Now if only they'll reprint this in Modern...
  To be honest, I think it's too powerful for Modern." — Epoa

     Not necessarily. We also do have Remand in Modern, which is quite similar:
     It gives basically the same effect, yet also lets both sides draw a card.
      (I love that we got a reprint of it in this very Duel Deck, by the way.
     That alone almost makes it worth the purchase, considering the steep price for the original Ravnica print.)

380200: Festerhide Boar.author: Ataraxiom
380200: Festerhide Boar.text_parsed:
Nago sees his second printing in MTG, and everybody cheers.

Vraska's deck is practically saturated in killspells, sacrifice outlets, and creatures with Deathtouch, so getting the Boar to come in as a 5/5 Trampler should never be hard to do. Most of Jace's creatures peak at 5/5 stats anyway, so you can be certain that you'll at least trade with whatever blocks you.

Be cautious of enemy bounce effects, however. Killing a creature will become far more difficult if you give the Jace deck time to get ahead in card advantage or tempo.

Edit: Whoa, I thought that this was in an uncommon slot. That's pretty solid.

380201: Control Magic.author: Ataraxiom
380201: Control Magic.text_parsed:
It's awesome to see this in Jace's deck rather than Mind Control.

Although I've had many great games with both cards, it was always nerve-wracking to see a Turn 3 creature hit the other side of the battlefield with nothing but Mind Control in my hand to answer it with. Even without haste, that beater has time to smash face before you steal it, and Turn 3 is often about the time that creatures start to get particularly threatening. It only gets worse if you're on the draw.

Dropping a steal effect just one turn earlier often makes the difference between taking initiative and taking damage, so I'm sure I'm not the only one who looks forward to using this against the Vraska deck this March.

380201: Control Magic.author: Reishyn
380201: Control Magic.text_parsed:
@ecthemage:

Because they do so much for just one card. Four mana is a steal for this card. You're getting a creature (which sometimes costs waay more to cast than Control Magic does), your opponent is losing a creature and, usually, it leaves you with the strongest creature on the battlefield. It can completely overturn a game's board state with a single casting. It's Blue removal that ignores the Indestructible rule and provides you with a potential finisher. All for 2UU! There's a reason Mind Control is basically this but harder to cast.

380203: Thought Scour.author: Ataraxiom
380203: Thought Scour.text_parsed:
Although I can see this being very useful in Jace's deck, I've really got to agree with N03y3D33R on this one; the art just doesn't feel right.

By saving Ravnica and becoming the Guildpact, Jace is supposed to have turned over a new leaf, right? We're supposed to see him as a redeemed hero who's outgrown his darker past, or at least somebody who's making an effort to be a good guy for a change.

This art was perfect for the horrific setting of Innistrad, but it's hard to look at it and imagine this happening under Jace's command in Ravnica. I'd have much rathered some new art, likely with a more abstract depiction of thoughts being taken away, maybe even for a constructive purpose.

380204: Stab Wound.author: Ataraxiom
380204: Stab Wound.text_parsed:
A card like this really highlights the difference between Jace's deck and Vraska's deck.

Whereas Vraska will be able to scape up some extra life here, and there, and everywhere, Jace's deck features no lifegain whatsoever.

Because of this, a card like Stab Wound really puts Jace on a serious clock. Two life a turn goes from being a threat to being an irreversible blow when you haven't got any lifegain to undo it with. Although it might be tempting to use this as a killspell, a clever Vraska will understand that dropping this on a Dream Stalker or Sea Gate Oracle will cause far more harm in the long run.

You don't even need to worry about killing the enchanted creature in combat; just sneak your attacking force past it with things like Shadow Alley Denizen and Rogue's Passage.

This has always been an elegant card, and I'm so happy to see it again.

380206: Jace's Mindseeker.author: Ataraxiom
380206: Jace's Mindseeker.text_parsed:
This card epitomizes everything that Jace's deck is about; it's a mill engine, it's card advantage, and it's a beefy Illusion all in one lovable package.

I'm sure there are plenty of players here who purchased the Psychic Labyrinth deck from M14, so most of us ought to already be familiar with this guy, for better or worse. Personally, I always liked tapping out for the fish, but I was often disappointed when I failed to mill over anything I could cast. It always felt like such a wasted opportunity when some huge blowout spell could have been waiting there for me.

Fortunately, Jace's deck has been very well designed and there's a clever way that you can make sure you'll mill into an Instant or Sorcery spell here. Once you have your 6 mana secured, leave the Mindseeker in your hand and keep two mana available for Memory Lapse. It's as simple as Lapsing a good spell and casting the Mindseeker next turn, folks.

If they don't cast anything worth Lapsing, Jace's deck is well-equipped with a variety of other Instant spells that you can dump the extra mana into, although I'm honestly a little disappointed that Chronomaton is Jace's only creature with a reusable ability that can be activated at instant speed.

380207: Wight of Precinct Six.author: Ataraxiom
380207: Wight of Precinct Six.text_parsed:
Don't underestimate this guy in Vraska's deck, he'll have more than enough to work with.

Jace's deck is far from being traditional control shell, as it features 20 creatures which could potentially end up in his graveyard. And although Vraska has only one traditional milling spell (Grisly Spectacle), she has a large array of killspells, discard magic, and creatures with Deathtouch, all which are sure to fill an opponent's graveyard with creatures.

In a strange way, Vraska's deck comes equipped with a creature-specific variety of milling, which is exactly what the Wight wants. You can expect to see him hit the table as a 4/4 or 6/6 pretty consistently, I think.

380210: Dream Stalker.text_parsed:
Worst case scenario, you use this guy to bounce one of the lands you tapped to cast him. That might give you an extra mana if you missed your land drop, or it might put you back a land drop if you've already played your land for the turn.

Best case scenario, you use this guy to bounce your Aether Adept or even your Jace's Mindseeker for crazy value.

It's so easy to forget that this guy is a 1/5 for just two mana. Those kind of stats make an aggro deck cry, and even hold off midrange for a few turns.

Personally, I just love that there are still cards like this that encourage creative deckbuilding.

380214: Vraska the Unseen.author: Ataraxiom
380214: Vraska the Unseen.text_parsed:
Although each of the Duel Decks is built well enough that they should be about equal against each other, it's easy to see which planeswalker is more powerful on their own here. (Hint: It's Vraska)

Vraska's +1 should be moderately useful against Jace's deck, especially since it allows her to survive being hit by a kicked Aether Figment and then follow up with a suicidal -3 the following turn.

Vraska's -3 is probably going to be the single most powerful effect in the entire Duel Deck, allowing her to destroy Jace's largest creatures, his Future Sight, his removal spells like Claustrophobia and Mind Control, and even Jace, Architect of Thought himself.

Vraska's -7 might see some use if a player is having an easier time against Jace, but I'm not certain how effective it'll be. Although Vraska's deck has more than enough creature removal and evasion tricks in it to make the Assassin tokens connect, the other deck runs a lot of bounce magic, which will destroy the tokens entirely.

I think that the biggest strength of Vraska here is how resilient she is against Jace's deck. While she has plenty of ways to destroy the planeswalker himself, he has very few ways of dealing with a resolved Vraska other than beating her down with his creatures. Most of Jace's spells which can target nonland permanents can only bounce them, and that will simply reset Vraska's loyalty for more -3 uses.

All the same, I'm really looking forward to seeing how these decks run against each other this March.

380216: Ray of Command.author: Ataraxiom
380216: Ray of Command.text_parsed:
With all of Vraska's Deathtouchers, this card should lead to some pretty amazing trickblocks.

Although the tapping is nice for keeping up the beatdown pace of Jace's deck, I personally believe that it's the instant speed that makes this card so powerful. Having just one of these in your deck is enough to make that other player doubt themselves in every single combat phase.

Most players count on losing a creature to a killspell in combat, some players might even count on a blocker being flashed into combat, but few players ever expect to lose an attacker and gain a blocker from the same spell. It's always surprising, and that's what makes it so fun.

Somewhere, somebody is going to steal one of Vraska's Assassin tokens and swing for game with it, and for a single fleeting moment, that individual will become a god o_o

380219: Phantasmal Bear.author: Ataraxiom
380219: Phantasmal Bear.text_parsed:
I should point out that the sacrifice drawback on Jace's Illusions isn't actually all that severe in the context of the Duel Decks because Vraska has very few cards that can target Jace's creatures which wouldn't normally kill them to begin with. Although cards like Consume Strength and Grisly Spectacle will target Jace's Illusions and kill them, it's likely that those cards were going to do that anyway, so the drawback is pretty negligible in those cases.

Any Jace player should be on the lookout for Shadow Alley Denizen and Rogue's Passage, however. Both of those cards are reusable sources of targeting, and can wipe out Illusions like the bear here very quickly.

380224: Reaper of the Wilds.author: SnesController
380224: Reaper of the Wilds.text_parsed: Activated hexproof: it's fair, because I only have it when I need it.
380224: Reaper of the Wilds.text_posted: Activated hexproof: it's fair, because I only have it when I need it.

380224: Reaper of the Wilds.author: Ataraxiom
380224: Reaper of the Wilds.text_parsed:
Now this was a quick reprint.

Our lady gorgon here is going to be a powerful beater in Vraska's deck, and I can guarantee that you'll be activating her second ability far more than her first. Most of Jace's creatures will be unable to deal 5 damage to the Reaper alone, and since you're not going up against any sweepers or non-targeting removal, having Hexproof is going to be a big deal.

Although being at 4CMC is going to get the Reaper out a turn earlier, be cautious if your local Jace is sitting on four untapped lands, as both Prohibit and Summoner's Bane require that much mana to counter her.

Having the only Scry effect in the Duel Decks should be a nice bonus for Vraska, but I can't help but to wonder how often Jace's milling will mess with it. Should be interesting to see just how well one deck works against the other this March.

380224: Reaper of the Wilds.author: Havrekjex
380224: Reaper of the Wilds.text_parsed:
In Standard, if you've got no mana open, it still doesn't die to:

Doom Blade
Ultimate Price
Mizzium Mortars
Warleader's Helix
Bile Blight
Lightning Strike
Anger of the Gods
Drown in Sorrow
Magma Jet

Out of all the most commonly played removal spells, this pretty much only leaves Detention Sphere, Dreadbore and Hero's Downfall. Yeah, I think Reaper is bound to make an impact on Standard at some point, either when JOU introduces the B/G scryland or after rotation.

380227: Underworld Connections.text_parsed: an activated Phyrexian Arena for 1 mana is good enough for me.
380227: Underworld Connections.text_posted: an activated [autocard]Phyrexian Arena [/autocard] for 1 mana is good enough for me.

380227: Underworld Connections.author: Ataraxiom
380227: Underworld Connections.text_parsed:
This is a great card for so many reasons.

Unlike the (in?)famous Phyrexian Arena, this actually gives you a choice of whether or not you want to pay the 1 life to draw a card. And although the Arena is probably better in general, the option to not pay life will be very appealing to many players, particularly newer players who are often skittish about losing life to their own cards.

I, like many others, will be happy to see the price of this card drop from $2.75 apiece. Eleven dollars for a playset of a great card might not sound like much, but a lot of us casuals need that money for rent and noodles.

This is an excellent addition to Vraska's deck, particularly because Jace has so few good answers to field enchantments. I expect this will go a long way to helping the Vraska players keep up with the Jaces in terms of card advantage.

380230: Stonefare Crocodile.author: Ataraxiom
380230: Stonefare Crocodile.text_parsed:
Even though this guy has gotten a pretty hard rap in the past, I've always liked him. He's in Golgari colours, but not necessarily Golgari-flavoured, and it was kind of cool to realize that there was still some unguilded members of nature out there somewhere in Ravnica.

In Vraska's deck, I think the lifelink ability will mostly go unused, but there's always the chance that he'll get buffed lategame by Consume Strength or Drooling Groodion and then activate his ability for a nice chunk of life.

His three power will allow him to take out a comfortable majority of Jace's creatures, and without any burn or traditional removal in that deck, I think he might survive longer than you'd expect.

A surprisingly solid common, always satisfying to play for some reason.

380231: Halimar Depths.author: Tribor
380231: Halimar Depths.text_parsed:
So first turn you could either:

Play Island, Ponder
or
Play Halimar Depths

Ponder thins your deck, Halimar Depths doesn't. Ponder also gives you the opportunity to shuffle for some better luck if all three top cards are bad draws. Ponder in essence has that extra versatility, but Halimar runs well in Landfall decks and some Moonfolk. Plus if you aren't short on mana, you won't mind playing it.

In conclusion, the two are good, running both isn't a bad idea.

380232: Dread Statuary.text_parsed: Nope, it's still a land, Vraska's -3 will never hit this card...
380232: Dread Statuary.text_posted: Nope, it's still a land, Vraska's -3 will never hit this card...

380232: Dread Statuary.author: Ataraxiom
380232: Dread Statuary.text_parsed:
Just like Chronomaton, this guy serves an important role in Jace's deck as an artifact creature.

Not only does his typing allow him to dodge Grisly Spectacle and block Vraska's Intimidate creatures, but being a manland also allows him to dodge her sorcery removal cards like Marsh Casualties.

Having four power should allow the Statuary to trade well with some of Vraska's tougher creatures, particularly valuable ones like Ohran Viper and Spawnwrithe. Not only that, but the Statuary will be a valuable attacker for beating face or knocking the last few loyalty counters off of Vraska herself, should the opportunity arise.

Remember, the statuary can only dodge Vraska's -3 as long as its not a creature, so be careful of activating it's ability during the other player's turn.

Edit: Holy, good eyes steinburger1109! I stand corrected, the Statuary can dodge Vraska's -3 even while it's in creature form. I suddenly like this guy a lot more in Jace's deck; there are far too few things in there that can avoid Vraska's -3. Excellent inclusion.

380233: Merfolk Wayfinder.author: anotherfan321
380233: Merfolk Wayfinder.text_parsed: Woah, how have I not seen this card before? This is such a strange effect in blue, but I guess they had to make the land theme work for all the colors in Zendikar. Neat card, for sure.
380233: Merfolk Wayfinder.text_posted: Woah, how have I not seen this card before? This is such a strange effect in blue, but I guess they had to make the land theme work for all the colors in Zendikar. Neat card, for sure.

380233: Merfolk Wayfinder.author: Ataraxiom
380233: Merfolk Wayfinder.text_parsed:
Although this effect would have fit really well into Zendikar, it feels sort of out of place in Jace's deck.

None of Jace's spells cost more than 6 mana, and those that cost more than 4 are the sort of spells that you're going to want to wait to use anyway, like Body Double or Spelltwine. I can understand the value of hitting your land drops more easily, but I feel as if simply drawing more cards would have been a better fit here...

Maybe something like Azure Mage to use your extra mana on, or Phantom Warrior to keep up the Illusion theme.

On the other hand, one of the best parts of premade decks is taking them apart and upgrading them, so maybe having the Wayfinder in here wasn't such a bad idea after all. Showing players (especially newer players) the different sides of a colour can be a really great teaching tool, and it helps to encourage new deck ideas far more than just having a streamlined deck design from the start.

380234: Rogue's Passage.author: Ataraxiom
380234: Rogue's Passage.text_parsed:
I think everybody realized that this card was made for Vraska's Assassin tokens even back during the original RTR block. Still, it does far more than that in her deck.

Making your Ohran Viper or Spawnwrithe unblockable for a turn can cause some serious problems for the Jace player, and if Jace, Architect of Thought ever hits the table, you can just swing at him with an unblockable beater regardless of whether he's got blockers up or not.

Beyond that, you can even use the Passage's ability to target Jace's Phantasmal Bear and Phantasmal Dragon to kill them outright. The best part is, Jace has literally zero spells in his deck that can interact with lands in any way!

So much utility bundled into one card, a wonderful addition to Vraska's deck.

380235: Treasured Find.author: Ladon---

I'm not sure why this is sitting at 2.5 stars right now, since it's literally the only graveyard recursion that Vraska's deck has been given. Seriously, Jace at least has Spelltwine and Body Double to work with, and he's not even in Golgari colours!

If you manage to draw Treasured Find before it gets milled away, hold onto it for a while. Many of Vraska's cards are particuarly hard for Jace's deck to deal with (River Boa and Vraska the Unseen, for example), so getting them back onto the battlefield a second time will really press your opponent for answers.

I'm super excited about this Duel Deck and it looks well thought-out, so maybe I'm being too hard on Vraska's lack of graveyard recursion. She's not really a part of the Golgari Swarm as far as the storyline goes, so it's possible that she's Black/Green, but in a different, nongraveyard-related way.

Superb card, though.

This guy has been a total workhorse in every set he's been reprinted in, and this one is no exception. He does everything Vraska's deck needs to win; he's card advantage, creature kill, and noncreature removal all bundled into one amorphous package.

The only problem with the Slime here is that you've only got one in the deck. With just Mold Shambler and Vraska the Unseen's -3 as alternatives, you'll be hard pressed to win the game if the opposing Jace player resolves a Future Sight after your Slime hits the battlefield.

All the same, this is a beautiful 5-drop that feels good to tap out for. This uncommon slot did not go to waste.

380238: Marsh Casualties.author: Ataraxiom
380238: Marsh Casualties.text_parsed:
If there's one card I can see gumming up a Vraska player's opening hand, it's this one. The BB casting cost is going to make it hard to cast in the first few turns, and even once you've secured enough mana to cast it, it won't do much of anything until you can kick it on Turn 5.

...no really, this card is very weak unkicked. Here's a list of the creatures it can kill in Jace's deck:

Aeon Chronicler, if the Jace player has one card in his hand.
Aether Figment, if the Jace player played it unkicked.
Crosstown Courier, reliably.
Jace's Phantasm, if the Jace player hasn't milled you for 10 yet.
Krovikan Mist, if the Jace player hasn't played any other Illusions.
Chronomaton, if the Jace player hasn't activated its ability yet.
Body Double, if the Jace player had it copy something with 1 toughness.
Control Magic, if the Jace player stole something with 1 toughness.
Ray of Command, if the Jace player stole something with 1 toughness during your turn.

In almost every one of these situations, the Jace player has some ability to prevent the Casualties from killing his creatures, and that's if he didn't use a counterspell in the first place!

Believe me folks, it might say BB, but this is a 5 mana spell.

380241: Aether Adept.author: Ataraxiom
380241: Aether Adept.text_parsed:
Back when I first started playing Magic, I had a dinky monoblue mill deck that my sister had put together for me. I remember it having creatures like Merfolk Mesmerist and Kraken Hatchling, which were perfectly fine for slowing the game down and milling, but were terrible in combat because of their lack of power.

After many frustrating combats, one of the first lessons I learned was that there was a huge difference between a creature having 1 power and a creature having 2 power. Aether Adept was one of the few creatures in my mill deck that had 2 power, and I was always happy to tap out for her and bounce one of my sister's creatures, knowing all too well that the Adept would be enough of a threat to make her think twice about swinging in at me.

It might be strange to older players, but this is a card that actually makes me feel nostalgic. Like the Serra Angel and Shivan Dragon of your days, Aether Adept has become a fond example of elegant card design from my earliest days of Magic.

Beautiful common, so happy to see her in Jace's deck.

380243: Errant Ephemeron.author: Ataraxiom
380243: Errant Ephemeron.text_parsed:
If nothing else, a card like this is fun. Everybody can watch it slowly tick down, and everybody can plan for it's eventual arrival. The game suddenly gains a whole new element of long-term strategy.

Being a blue mage, you ought to be able to take all this into consideration and outwit your opponent. An enemy player is likely to hold onto a killspell to deal with the Ephemeron when it arrives, so maybe you'll save a counterspell for that killspell, or maybe you'll just let it soak up the hate, or maybe you'll just pretend to be doing one while you actually do the other, the possibilities are endless!

But honestly, isn't blue all about planning for the endgame?

380244: Vinelasher Kudzu.author: Ataraxiom
380244: Vinelasher Kudzu.text_parsed:
There are some underpowered cards in Vraska's deck that will do surprisingly well due to the way that Jace's deck is built. This is a powerful card that will do surprisingly badly for the same reason.

Don't get me wrong, this is a fantastic beater and there are plenty of decktypes that it will defeat almost singlehandedly, even against talented players... but Jace's Duel Deck is probably not one of them.

Jace has four counterspells (all of which can target the Kudzu), four bounce-type spells which will reset the Kudzu's +1/+1 counters, and four other noncreature spells that can steal or incapacitate the Kudzu in some way.

Early game the Kudzu will be kept at bay by these spells, and lategame it'll be outclassed by Jace's larger Illusion creatures. If nothing else, this guy will act as a lightning rod to provide cover for some of your other resources.

Bad match-up, excellent card. Glad to have it in the pack just for the sake of getting one.

Jace has four counterspells (all of which can target the Kudzu), four bounce-type spells which will reset the Kudzu's +1/+1 counters, and four other noncreature spells that can steal or incapacitate the Kudzu in some way.

Early game the Kudzu will be kept at bay by these spells, and lategame it'll be outclassed by Jace's larger Illusion creatures. If nothing else, this guy will act as a lightning rod to provide cover for some of your other resources.

Bad match-up, excellent card. Glad to have it in the pack just for the sake of getting one.

380245: Jace's Phantasm.author: Ataraxiom
380245: Jace's Phantasm.text_parsed:
The elegant thing about Jace's deck is that it doesn't feature many "brute-force" milling spells like Mind Sculpt, which admittedly would have fit right into the theme.

Because of this, getting your Phantasm to turn into a 5/5 is going to take some work, but it's certainly possible. Crosstown Courier will net you some mill if he connects, Thought Scour is a cheap way to gain mill and maintain card advantage, and if you're lucky enough to find your Jace's Mindseeker, you'll be halfway to your 10 cards with that alone!

It's easy to forget that your opponent will be tossing cards into their graveyard naturally, but with Vraska as Jace's enemy deck, it's just as possible that those cards will be crawling right back onto the battlefield.

Personally, I think it's pretty cool that the Duel Decks will be fighting the war on two fronts; one fight for board advantage, and one fight for the graveyard as a resource in itself.

380246: Consume Strength.author: Ataraxiom
380246: Consume Strength.text_parsed:
Back during RTR Block Standard, I happened to link into this card while looking at Rites of Reaping. Needless to say, I was more than a little disappointed at what we had been given to work with.

This card is the beautiful unholy marriage between Green and Black combat tricks, and it fills its spot in Vraska's deck perfectly. Since Vraska has relatively few noncreature spells, dropping a Consume Strength in the middle of combat will almost always get a surprised reaction out of whoever's sitting across from you.

Occasionally you'll be lucky enough to drop this for a 2 for 1, but I can imagine that it'll mostly be used to allow your Reach blockers to take out Jace's bigger fliers, like Krovikan Mist or Jace's Phantasm.

If you're looking to tweak Vraska's deck, it's a safe bet that you can start by getting more of these. You'll always be happy to see one in your hand.

I can't believe it's in a common slot.

380247: Sea Gate Oracle.author: Ataraxiom
380247: Sea Gate Oracle.text_parsed:
I like this guy way better in this deck than Merfolk Wayfinder.

Although he doesn't dig quite as deep, the Oracle has the potential to find you cards that are far better than lands, or maybe even just lands if that's what you need at the time. I can understand Wizards wanting to add flavour by giving Jace Merfolk in his deck, but the idea of having to send Jace's Mindseeker or Body Double or Spelltwine to the bottom of my library is just too upsetting to bear.

Keeping the second card out of your graveyard should help ward off Vraska's shenanigans a little, too.

380248: Oran-Rief Recluse.author: Ataraxiom
380248: Oran-Rief Recluse.text_parsed:
Creatures in Jace's deck come in two flavours: Hilariously tiny and horrifically large.

Vraska's deck has a wide range of removal spells. Spells like Last Kiss, Marsh Casualties, and Consume Strength are for Jace's tiny creatures. Spells like Nekrataal, Grisly Spectacle, and Tragic Slip are for Jace's larger creatures.

Although the Recluse here might seem a little bland, it's important to rememeber that Jace has a lot of dangerous fliers. When you've got Jace's Mindseeker, or Jace's Phantasm, or Krovikan Mist staring you down, you'll be glad to know that there's just one more killspell in your deck somewhere.

Probably better than people are giving it credit for.

380249: Mold Shambler.author: Ataraxiom
380249: Mold Shambler.text_parsed:
Geez man... I was almost starting to think that the Vraska deck was underpowered, but then this pops up.

How many answers do you suppose Jace has to Vraska the Unseen?

...are you thinking?

Very few. He can delay Vraska with Into the Roil, Memory Lapse, Remand, and Riftwing Cloudskate, or beat her down directly with AEther Figment. But Vraska's +1 and -3 can both kill the Figment, and bouncing her will just reset her loyalty for more -3 uses. It seems that the best that Jace can do is either try to mill Vraska out of her library, or lose his creatures beating her down. It's not a pretty picture.

Meanwhile, Vraska's deck has a slew of answers for Jace, Architect of Thought. Corpse Traders, Hypnotic Cloud, and Slate Street Ruffian can all force Jace to be discarded before he can hit the table, and if he does, Shadow Alley Denizen, Rogue's Passage, and River Boa can all beat him down with unblockable damage.

Alternatively, the Shambler here and Vraska's -3 can just kill Jace directly, no questions asked.

380252: Archaeomancer.author: Ataraxiom
380252: Archaeomancer.text_parsed:
Another beautiful common for Jace's deck. Some players might bemoan paying 4 mana for a 1/2 creature, but I've always enjoyed the steeper cost of this card.

I'm not sure if there's a word for it, but some cards just feel satisfying to tap out for, as if their mana cost gives the card some sort of literal weight. One of the more amusing parts of a card like Archaeomancer is that your opponent will often be annoyed at the card advantage it brings you, but just won't feel right about wasting removal on it. It's just a 1/2 after all, what harm could it do?

And then they realize that the card you returned to your hand was Peel from Reality.

380254: Corpse Traders.author: Ataraxiom
380254: Corpse Traders.text_parsed:
I'm actually a little disappointed at the lack of utility that this card will give Vraska's deck. Of all her cards, only four of them will benefit from having creatures sacrificed. That's far fewer than I had expected from a deck in Golgari colours.

For those who're curious, the four cards are Sadistic Augermage, Tragic Slip, Festerhide Boar, and Reaper of the Wilds. The Reaper is the only one on the list who will enjoy repeated activiations, but she's definitely an excellent card all around.

I should also note that Treasured Find is the only card in Vraska's entire deck that allows you to recover resources from your graveyard, so be careful with what you're throwing away; it might not be easy to get back again.

380255: Remand.author: Ataraxiom
380255: Remand.text_parsed:
The fact that Jace's version of Remand features Azorius flavourtext kind of pokes at a question that's been in my mind ever since Jace became the new Guildpact.

Since Jace is taking over for Azor, who was almost certainly Blue/White, does this mean that Jace is going to start leaning toward the White side of Blue's allied wedge on the colour pie? His new artwork kind of suggests that, given the colour scheme of his Planeswalker Card.

All the same, I think that with Venser so fresh in everybody's mind, Wizards might be hesitant to make Jace into a Blue/White walker. But on the other hand, Venser is gone in the story now, so maybe that's an opening in design space that needs to be filled?

Just a thought.

380255: Remand.author: Reishyn
380255: Remand.text_parsed:
@SUPERCOW

Remand is definitely more versatile as you can use it to bounce one of your own spells gone wrong or force your opponent to discard on a full hand. Memory Lapse has versatility in a mill deck but Remand does so much more on its own. Also, the fact that it cantrips means you aren't losing card advantage by playing it and gives it value if you're just trying to stall out the game until you get that one card you badly need. (Something I've had first hand experience with many times.)

Memory Lapse is an amazing card and impacts the opponent more. If you have a deck that builds around it, or a deck with something that Memory Lapse builds around itself, then yes, it can be much more devastating. But Remand is just waaay too handy to overlook in any deck that uses counter magic.

380256: Crosstown Courier.author: Ataraxiom
380256: Crosstown Courier.text_parsed:
I think that many players dislike cards like this because they consider mill redundant when it comes attached to combat damage. Honestly, I can't blame people for taking this stance when the numbers seem so convincing. I mean, why bother milling your opponent out when you can just smash face for the win?

2 Cards/60 Cards = 1/30 or 3.333% of a Win Condition
2 Life/20 Life = 1/10 or 10% of a Win Condition

However, there's something here that newer players overlook.

Life loss is mathematically discrete; because your life total is generally not a resource (barring the occasional black spell), your deck will operate just as well at 1 life as it will at 20. Generally speaking again, smashing face does nothing for you until you can deal that last point of damage, or at least threaten to do so.

Milling is mathematically continuous; because the cards in a deck are a resource which is guaranteed to be used by the player, your deck will not operate as well at 1 card as it will at 60. Every time you mill an opponent, even if it's just a couple of cards, you've essentially reached into the machine that is their deck, and pulled out a fistful of cogs.

In the case of cards like the Courier here, the milling is intended to compliment the damage. You're probably going to win the game by beating face, but in the meantime, milling over killspells and potential blockers is going to make that a whole lot easier.

Ataraxiom has a great point, and there's something else I'd like to mention:

The main idea behind this creature is not to mill. It is supposed to be another Coral Merfolk-esque creature. What they added was a secondary ability that makes this better than the generic Coralfolk or Goblin Piker. It's a little added bonus, like Vigilance or First Strike.

So when you think of this creature, think of it as a light attacker with a little bit of utili-mill. When I did, it looks better than it is.

380256: Crosstown Courier.author: Thornhillforge
380256: Crosstown Courier.text_parsed:
@Ataraxion: There is an argument to be made for simultaneous damage and milling, but I'm a bit surprised by this one. Milling their kill spells and blockers doesn't actually reduce the quality of their card draws. For instance, if you mill a worthless card on top of that crucial land that they need to get going, then you essentially just did the other player a favor.
The argument that supports incidental mill is when you are using a deck that uses the graveyard as a resource. Rather than hurting your opponent, I see this kind of mill as a way to buff your Jace's Phantasm or prime your Spelltwine with more potential targets.

380257: Leyline Phantom.author: Ataraxiom
380257: Leyline Phantom.text_parsed:
Judging from the one star rating, this guy isn't going over all that well with the folks here on Gatherer. Normally I'd try to say something positive here but honestly... I can't find much to work with on this one.

He's a 5/5 beater in a relevant tribe for Jace's deck, so that's definitely something. But that ability...

Jace has no cards in his deck which synergize well with this guy returning to your hand repeatedly, so I thought that maybe it was there as protection against Vraska's sorceries, right?

Well... not so much.

Most of Vraska's killspells are at instant speed, and the ones that are at sorcery speed aren't even spells which would normally be able to kill the Phantom, like Marsh Casualties. To make matters worse, a lot of Vraska's sorcery speed mechanics are discard effects, meaning that the Phantom is actually more vulnerable to them because it will often be in your hand.

Although there's the rare situation where the Phantom will dodge a Nekrataal effect or shake off a Stab Wound, for the most part his ability is going to be a massive downside in a deck that's focused on beating face as quickly as possible.

380257: Leyline Phantom.author: Ferlord
380257: Leyline Phantom.text_parsed:
@Quotations, you're right to believe that it might discourage your opponent from attacking (since you'll be able to block and not have a dead creature after), but I think it may also encourage your opponent to attack.

If I had a 1/1 (let's say I'm playing Fugitive Wizard for some reason) and I attacked with it, would you block it? You wouldn't, because then you'd have to pay another for the Phantasm just to kill a 1/1 (a fugitive wizard, no less). So then you'd take 1 damage. Would you rather have a blocker that won't simply go away when something small comes around?

Mind YOU, that can be a ploy that'll allow you to attack them with a 5/5. Once it deals damage, you play it again, untapped and ready to go.

One way or another, it's an okay card. 5-cost blue common creatures are never 5/5's without some kind of 'negative' clause.

380258: Spelltwine.author: Ataraxiom
380258: Spelltwine.text_parsed:
I'm a little disappointed that Vraska's deck only has 7 or 8 instants and sorceries for Spelltwine to choose from. Two of those cards have kicker costs that will be unusable with Spelltwine, and one of those cards (Treasured Find) will have a good chance of being exiled by the time you get the chance to steal it in the first place.

Don't get me wrong, Spelltwine is a wonderful, powerful card, but it just isn't all that effective against a creature-heavy deck like Vraska's.


Edit: I stand corrected, it looks like the kicker costs will be usable after all. That helps somewhat.

"If you cast a card "without paying its mana cost," you can't pay any alternative costs. You can pay additional costs such as kicker costs. If the card has mandatory additional costs, you must pay those."
380258: Spelltwine.text_posted:
I'm a little disappointed that Vraska's deck only has 7 or 8 instants and sorceries for Spelltwine to choose from. Two of those cards have kicker costs that will be unusable with Spelltwine, and one of those cards ([autocard]Treasured Find[/autocard]) will have a good chance of being exiled by the time you get the chance to steal it in the first place.

Don't get me wrong, Spelltwine is a wonderful, powerful card, but it just isn't all that effective against a creature-heavy deck like Vraska's.


Edit: I stand corrected, it looks like the kicker costs will be usable after all. That helps somewhat.

[b]"If you cast a card "without paying its mana cost," you can't pay any alternative costs. You can pay additional costs such as kicker costs. If the card has mandatory additional costs, you must pay those."[/b]

380260: River Boa.author: Continue
380260: River Boa.text_parsed: There was a time when this was the two-drop to beat, and its reprint in Jace vs. Vraska shows that even after seventeen years, it's still quite the force. Welcome back, Wall of Regenerating Snake.
380260: River Boa.text_posted: There was a time when this was the two-drop to beat, and its reprint in Jace vs. Vraska shows that even after seventeen years, it's still quite the force. Welcome back, Wall of Regenerating Snake.

380260: River Boa.author: Ataraxiom
380260: River Boa.text_parsed:
Oh wow... here's a doozy.

Needless to say, any Jace player unfortunate enough to be sitting across from this thing is going to have a hard match. Having two power lets the Boa trade with a lot of Jace's smaller creatures, and the Regeneration ability is almost always going to be used effectively. Jace has no traditional killspells to use on the snake anyway, so you'll pretty much always know when to leave the mana open for regenerating.

On the fairer side of things, being a 2CMC creature makes the Boa vulnerable to all of Jace's counterspells, two of which will send it to the graveyard. (The other two will send it somewhere else to be recasted later on.)

Considering that Jace also has a good range of bounce spells, I've got a feeling that the Boa will spend a lot of time off the battlefield, but not much of it in the graveyard.

Bound to cause plenty of trouble, just what Vraska wants. An excellent uncommon.

380262: Death-Hood Cobra.author: Ataraxiom
380262: Death-Hood Cobra.text_parsed:
Although Deadly Recluse is generally better than the Cobra, I think that they chose this card for Vraska's deck because it fits the flavour a little better.

To be fair, there are actually very few snakes in Magic that aren't linked to an out-of-place mechanic like poison counters or an out-of-place setting like Kamigawa. Jace's deck is chock-full of fliers and the Cobra's Reach ability gives Vraska an answer to them.

All the same, I'm a little disappointed that Ambush Viper wasn't reprinted into Vraska's deck. It's an awesome snake, and having another spell to play at instant speed would have been wonderful, as there are only four instants in her deck before you tweak it.

380265: Ohran Viper.author: Ataraxiom
380265: Ohran Viper.text_parsed:
Man these decks are just loaded with first-time reprints, I love it.

Like Vraska's Slate Street Ruffian, the Viper here is bound to cause some hard blocking decisions for the other player. The only difference is that the Viper does it so much better. Even without full-fledged Deathtouch, you can be swinging in with this guy almost every turn and expect good results because all of Jace's creatures with more than 2 power are bound to be valuable assets to his deck's operation. I'm serious, Jace has next to no 3 power chump blockers to take the Viper out with.

So what does that mean? It means that the Viper is either drawing you cards, or tearing Jace's field apart. Either way, this makes Vraska a happy gorgon.

More than worthy of a rare slot.

380269: Chronomaton.text_parsed: This isn't 2.3 tier quality. This is a defender who's always on curve, then an attacker when you want it to be. A 2/2 on T2, a 3/3 on T3, a 4/4 on T4... and the moment you feel that you don't need your 5/5 or 6/6 to improve, it can become a strong offensive presence. 380269: Chronomaton.author: Ataraxiom
380269: Chronomaton.text_parsed:
As one of Jace's only two artifact creatures (the other being an animated Dread Statuary), this guy will play an important role against Vraska's deck.

Not only can he dodge Grisly Spectacle, but his artifact typing also allows him to block creatures which have been given Intimidate by Vraska's Shadow Alley Denizen. Additionally, he's another excellent one-drop for Jace's beatdown strategy, and can even grow as the game goes on.

Since you'll likely spend a turn or two sitting on counterspell mana, remember that you can leave this guy untapped, block with him, and then tap him to use that extra mana to buff him before combat damage is even dealt. That should help you cut your losses if the Vraska player decides not to play anything worth countering.

I always liked the flavour of this little guy, and it's great to see him earn his first reprint. Good going Wizards.

380273: Nekrataal.text_parsed:
I can see this becoming one of the highest rated cards in Jace vs. Vraska simply based on its flavour alone. It's remarkable that some cards can have four or five lines of flavour text and fail to capture the meaning that this one does with six words.

Honestly, the fact that Vraska is saying this tells us so much about her and Jace. She's admitting that Jace is more than capable of protecting some or even most of the innocents in Ravnica, but she's taunting him for the fact that she knows he can never stop her entirely. Every life lost is another weight on Jace's conscience, something that she as a cold-blooded killer has probably never had to endure.

It also tells us that Jace is truly making progress in his inner conflict between the Black and White aspects of his personality. In the past, Jace had been morally ambiguous as he tried to decide whether he wanted to use his powers to defend people or simply dominate them, and it's been really cool to see him develop into a legitimately caring person who accepts the responsibility of protecting so many people.

Maybe Jace will someday fill the shoes of Venser as a Blue/White walker?

380273: Nekrataal.author: UKenobi
380273: Nekrataal.text_parsed:
One of the few older cards that really has been able to stand the test of time. Still one of my favorite black creatures of all time.

And yeah, that flavor text is pretty sweet. The art's cool, too. I'm glad that they gave a card that has so much nostalgia for me its justice in its reprint. I've been waiting to see this guy again for too long.

380274: Grisly Spectacle.author: Ataraxiom
380274: Grisly Spectacle.text_parsed:
Actually, I really like having this card in Vraska's deck. Many of Jace's creatures have the potential to be quite large, so the Spectacle will often mill for 4 or 5 cards upon resolution. Between this and all the discard that'll be going on in Vraska's deck, her Wight of Precinct Six could really get out of hand in a hurry.

And flavourwise, this is just a homerun. Remember that Vraska is basically a hired assassin, and not a true member of the Golgari Swarm, so her work will often have her killing for whoever makes it the most convenient at the time. Since Jace is trying to maintain peace in Ravnica, the seemingly-random killings of Vraska are both alarming and uncontrollable, threatening to start yet another Guild War.

The flavourtext on Nekrataal really sends the message home.

380275: Krovikan Mist.author: Ataraxiom
380275: Krovikan Mist.text_parsed:
With at least 10 different Illusion creatures in Jace's deck (this fellow included), it shouldn't be uncommon to see the Mist swinging in for 4 or 5 damage at a time, often alongside a Phantasmal Dragon or Jace's Phantasm, both of which have the potential to be 5/5 beaters as well.

It's interesting to see Blue being so aggressive, especially with the other Duel Deck being part Green. Big creatures are particularly exciting for newer players, so I've got a feeling that these decks will go over really well with casual players like myself.

Honestly, I'm pumped to plunk down the $25 or $30 to enjoy an afternoon battling back and forth with a friend. The best part is, these decks are perfect for teaching new players how to play the game, and both decks just beg to be tweaked and upgraded, so the fun lasts a whole lot longer than the original decks ever will.
